query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
25 Lì si cantò non Bacco, non Peana, 26 ma tre persone in divina natura, 27 e in una persona essa e l’umana.
query.result: 25 There it was sung not Bacchus, not Peana, 26 but three persons in divine nature, 27 and in one person it is and the human.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
28 Compié ’l cantare e ’l volger sua misura; 29 e attesersi a noi quei santi lumi, 30 felicitando sé di cura in cura.

Please translate each line literally into English.
31 Ruppe il silenzio ne’ concordi numi 32 poscia la luce in che mirabil vita 33 del poverel di Dio narrata fumi,
34 e disse: «Quando l’una paglia è trita, 35 quando la sua semenza è già riposta, 36 a batter l’altra dolce amor m’invita.
query.result:
31 It broke the silence among the harmonious gods 32 then the light in which marvelous life 33 of the little poor one of God narrated smoke,
34 and said: “When the one straw is ground, 35 when its seed is already put away, 36 to beat the other sweet love invites me.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
37 Tu credi che nel petto onde la costa 38 si trasse per formar la bella guancia 39 il cui palato a tutto ’l mondo costa,
40 e in quel che, forato da la lancia, 41 e prima e poscia tanto sodisfece, 42 che d’ogne colpa vince la bilancia,
43 quantunque a la natura umana lece 44 aver di lume, tutto fosse infuso 45 da quel valor che l’uno e l’altro fece;
46 e però miri a ciò ch’io dissi suso, 47 quando narrai che non ebbe ’l secondo 48 lo ben che ne la quinta luce è chiuso.
query.result:
37 You believe that in the chest where the rib 38 was drawn to form the beautiful cheek 39 whose palate costs the whole world,
40 and in that which, pierced by the lance, 41 and first and afterwards so much satisfied, 42 that the balance overcomes every fault,
43 however much it harms human nature 44 to have light, everything would be infused, 45 by that valor that made the one and the other;
46 and therefore look at that which I said above, 47 when I narrated that the second did not have 48 the good that in the fifth light is closed.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
49 Or apri li occhi a quel ch’io ti rispondo, 50 e vedräi il tuo credere e ’l mio dire 51 nel vero farsi come centro in tondo.
query.result: 49 Now open the eyes to that which I answer you, 50 and I would see your belief and my saying 51 in the true becoming as a center in round.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 Ciò che non more e ciò che può morire 53 non è se non splendor di quella idea 54 che partorisce, amando, il nostro Sire;
55 ché quella viva luce che sì mea 56 dal suo lucente, che non si disuna 57 da lui né da l’amor ch’a lor s’intrea,
58 per sua bontate il suo raggiare aduna, 59 quasi specchiato, in nove sussistenze, 60 etternalmente rimanendosi una.

query.result:
61 Thus it descends to the ultimate powers 62 down from act to act, so becoming, 63 that it does nothing but brief contingencies;
64 and these contingencies being I understand 65 the generated things, which produces 66 with seed and without seed the heaven moving.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
67 La cera di costoro e chi la duce 68 non sta d’un modo; e però sotto ’l segno 69 idëale poi più e men traluce.
query.result: 67 The wax of them and who leads it 68 does not stay in one way; and therefore under the sign 69 ideal then more and less shines through

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
70 Ond’ elli avvien ch’un medesimo legno, 71 secondo specie, meglio e peggio frutta; 72 e voi nascete con diverso ingegno.

query.result:
73 If the wax were at the point deduced 74 and the sky were in its supreme virtue, 75 the light of the seal would seem whole;
76 but nature always gives it feeble, 77 similarly working to the artist 78 who, to the habit of art, has a hand that trembles.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
79 Però se ’l caldo amor la chiara vista 80 de la prima virtù dispone e segna, 81 tutta la perfezion quivi s’acquista.
query.result: 79 But if the warm love the clear sight 80 of the first virtue arranges and marks, 81 all the perfection there is acquired

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
88 Or s’i’ non procedesse avanti piùe, 89 ‘Dunque, come costui fu sanza pare?’ 90 comincerebber le parole tue.
query.result: 88 Now if I did not proceed further forward, 89 “Thus, how was this one without seeming?” 90 your words would begin.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
91 Ma perché paia ben ciò che non pare, 92 pensa chi era, e la cagion che ’l mosse, 93 quando fu detto “Chiedi”, a dimandare.
query.result: 91 But why does it seem well that which does not seem, 92 think who was, and the cause that moved him, 93 when it was said “Ask”, to ask.

103 Wherefore, if that which I said and this note, 104 royal prudence is that uneven seeing 105 in which the stral of my intention strikes;
106 and if to the “surse” you raise the clear eyes, 107 you will see to have only respect 108 to the kings, who are many, and the good are rare.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
109 Con questa distinzion prendi ’l mio detto; 110 e così puote star con quel che credi 111 del primo padre e del nostro Diletto.

Please translate each line literally into English.
112 E questo ti sia sempre piombo a’ piedi, 113 per farti mover lento com’ uom lasso 114 e al sì e al no che tu non vedi:
115 ché quelli è tra li stolti bene a basso, 116 che sanza distinzione afferma e nega 117 ne l’un così come ne l’altro passo;
118 perch’ elli ’ncontra che più volte piega 119 l’oppinïon corrente in falsa parte, 120 e poi l’affetto l’intelletto lega.

Please translate each line literally into English.
121 Vie più che ’ndarno da riva si parte, 122 perché non torna tal qual e’ si move, 123 chi pesca per lo vero e non ha l’arte.
query.result: 121 Ways more than to go from the shore they part, 122 because it does not return just as it moves, 123 who fishes for the truth and does not have the art.

124 And of this are to the world opened proofs 125 Parmenides, Melissus and Brissus and many, 126 the ones who went and did not know where;
127 thus did Sabellius and Arius and those foolish 128 who were like swords to the Scriptures 129 in rendering crooked the right faces.

139 Do not believe woman Berta and Sir Martino, 140 to see a theft, to offer another, 141 to see them within the divine counsel;
142 because that one can arise, and that one can fall.
